p: Lavandula pubescens, also known as downy lavender, is an aromatic flowering plant belonging to the Lamiaceae family. Lavandula, consisting of approximately 39 known species, has been largely cultivated as ornamental plants for gardens and scenery use. This perennial plant is widely distributed in the Mediterranean, North Africa, Southwest Asia, western Iran, and eastern India [ 1]. The widely used and cultivated lavender species are Lavandula angustifolia, Lavandula officinalis, Lavandula latifolia, and Lavandula vera. Lavandula pubescens is a newly discovered species of lavender, which occurs in the Mediterranean. In recent years, the plants have been extensively studied as resources for medicine and aromatic products and used largely for their medicinal potentials, because these plants contain a number of bioactive compounds that act against human and plant pathogens [ 2], as well as compounds with various activities and properties [ 3].
